> From: Herr Christian Wolfgang Hujer [mailto:Christian.Hujer@...]
>=
 
> I'd like to know wethere there's a comprehensive Unit Testing 
> Glossa=
ry out there, explaining at least:
> Dummy
> Mock
> Stub
> Different kinds =
of Tests (Unit, Performance, Integration, 
> Interaction, System, Functiona=
l, Acceptance, Component etc.
> etc.)
> Invariants, Preconditions, Postcond=
itions
> When to use Exceptions, when to use internal Assertions, when to u=
se Unit 
> Tests.
> 
> Is there such a glossary?

A commonly used glossary =
of terms such as these and more is the British testing standards organizati=
on's BS 7925-1: http://www.testingstandards.co.uk/bs_7925-1.htm.  On that p=
age you can get a free copy of the pre-final draft, and also link to the "l=
iving" glossary online.

I've preferred to check out multiple sources for a=
 lot of testing terms, and use them to help me decide based on my experienc=
e and own thought.  Basing one's theory of the world *just* on given dictio=
nary definitions is thoughtless and careless, in my opinion.  But a glossar=
y can be a good start.  Books by Binder, Beizer, Myers and Hetzel are great=
 sources for good QA terminology, but they sometimes disagree, which is whe=
re you have to think for yourself.

I wrote up a survey of load testing ter=
minology and my own conclusions in this QA newsletter last year, if interes=
ted: http://www.soft.com/News/QTN-Online/qtnsep02.html

Scott Stirling
